speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: We will now hear argument in Orff against the United States. Mr. Smiland.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Mr. Smiland, do you mind telling us why the petitioners never filed suit in the Court of Federal Claims?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is it concurrent? I mean, the -- the statute I'm reading, the one you brought is consent is given to join the United States as a necessary party defendant. Is that what happened here? They were joined as a necessary party defendant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They were? I -- I think that's -- isn't that -- what rule of -- I thought there's a -- a Rule of Federal Procedure. I can't remember what -- what's the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes. Is that what they were joined under?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No. Well, all right. Were Page 4 they -- there's technical phrase well known in the law to be joined as a necessary party defendant.  Given the normal meaning in the law of that technical phrase, is that what happened here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, okay.  If it did not happen, then how could you possibly sue in that court rather than the Court of Claims where the statute says you can sue on any implied, as well as express, contract?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It doesn't mean in any suit in sentence 2 of the kind referred to in sentence 1?  Does it mean any suit in the universe?  Any suit in the world? Any tort suit?  I would have thought that sentence 2 refers to sentence 1.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But don't -- how can we, if we have -- if -- if I read this -- this as meaning technically what it says and it's a jurisdictional matter, how could I do anything other than say, go to the Court of Page 5 Claims, you're in the wrong court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes. It says --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- in any suit you can join the United States as a necessary party.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, but we don't give broad construction to waivers of sovereign immunity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Quite the reverse. And it says to join the U.S. as a necessary party defendant in a suit to adjudicate, confirm, validate, or decree the contractual rights of a contracting entity in the United States regarding any contract executed pursuant. Now, I guess the farmers were not technically the contracting entity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: So you've got more problems.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If you -- if the lower courts were of this view, why did the district court in this case give you three opportunities to have your contract claim transferred to the Claims Court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it does suggest that the district court had at least some concern whether the case -- your claim had been lodged in the right court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, but it's a -- see, I want to know what I'm supposed to do.  As I read the language, you're out.  As I understand the purpose of the statute, Page 7 it makes sense to me if you're out, and it doesn't make sense to me if you're in.  And maybe there's some lower court precedent to the contrary, which I'd certainly read, but is there any Supreme Court precedent to the contrary that supports you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no.  But that isn't the limiting part.  The limiting part is in any suit of a certain kind.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What they give consent to is joinder as a necessary party.  And that is not what happened here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's ordinary meaning, you're out because the ordinary meaning of joinder as a necessary party is you weren't joined as a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, it's something that I hadn't concentrated on before now, but your position that, Page 8 well, if you're transferred to the Court -- to the Court of Claims, that you bring with you all of the previous rulings of the United States district court in California and that those are somehow binding because of the law of the case -- what is the authority for that?  The -- the court that's transferred has to accept all the rulings that have been made previous to the transfer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, what's the authority for that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Could I -- I -- I guess I'm not following this.  I don't know why, Mr. Smiland, you -- you have not referred to the last sentence of -- of what you assert was the waiver of sovereign immunity, which says any suit pursuant to this section may be brought in any United States district court in the State in which the land involved is situated.  Why isn't that what you're relying on?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: How does that help you? Because it says any suit pursuant to this section, and of course, this section starts off by talking about addition of a person as a necessary party.  So how does the last sentence help you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I -- I take that to mean that when you sue one defendant and you also sue the United States as a necessary party defendant, that suit -- any -- that would be a suit pursuant to this section. I -- I don't know what other meaning that -- that sentence could have.  When you sue two parties, one of whom is the United States, by reason of the fact that it's a necessary party defendant, that suit is a suit pursuant this section and it can be brought in any United States district court in the State in which the land involved is situated.  I -- I don't know what -- what other suit that -- that sentence could refer to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You -- you agree with that.  I -- you're caught in between us here, and I understand. Page 10 (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And I guess we have to figure out what is the right meaning of that initial phrase.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Perhaps you can explain. This was not your suit originally. You intervened. Right? This was started out by the water district.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And then after some, I think, 2 years --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the water district bows out. It has settled its case. It's a mystery what it settled for. At least, I didn't see it in any of the briefs. Why did the water district, having brought this case, then say, we're satisfied, we're out?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Smiland, can I ask this question?  If Justice Breyer is -- the thrust of his question is right, I -- I think the district itself could not have brought the suit under his reading of the sovereign immunity.  And I'm just wondering, has the United States ever taken the position that the district could not have initiated this litigation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Could -- could we hear your argument on -- on the sovereign immunity point as opposed to the venue point?  What -- on what ground do you say the United States has waived its -- its immunity from suit in this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May -- may we just back up to the question -- your answer to Justice Stevens?  I thought that this wasn't a suit initially on the part of the water district for money damages.  I thought they were seeking declaratory relief against the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Because one could -- one could read the words, suit to adjudicate, confirm, validate, or decree the contractual rights, as a suit for declaratory relief but not encompassing damages.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can you turn to sovereign immunity now?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and let me make -- make it easy for you.  Do you know of any case, other than Page 13 cases decided by this friendly district judge, in which a suit has been allowed against the United States based on nothing more than the status as a third party beneficiary of a contract to which the United States has -- on which the United States has agreed to be sued?  Is -- is there any such case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and you think it's clear that -- as our sovereign immunity law requires, that such a third party beneficiary can sue the United States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I -- I don't understand that. The rights were all inclusive. As -- as I understand the law of third party beneficiaries, it -- it used to be -- and -- and perhaps at the time this statute was enacted still was -- quite -- quite restrictive.  It's only in more recent -- I don't agree with the Government's argument that -- that you have to, in an ordinary contract, explicitly refer to the third party beneficiary's rights.  But when sovereign immunity is at issue, it's -- it's a different question, it seems Page 14 to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Because -- because we have a rule that says when Congress wants the United States to be sued, it -- it must say so clearly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But yes, isn't it arguable, though, that in this case the Government probably thought that it would be efficient to have the district represent all the farmers for whatever their -- to the extent their interests were shared with one another, rather than having every individual have the same right to bring -- bring a lawsuit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Except for the fact that the district is the party to the contract, though.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but the -- the whole point of the district -- correct if I'm wrong.  This is your area.  The whole point of the district was to make it easier for the United States to know with whom it was dealing to have an efficient system, and if you say, well, that doesn't include lawsuits for damages, it seems to me that destroys much of the purpose of the formation of the district.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you haven't really achieved very much efficiency if you simply get the United States out of the business of collecting the payments and of keeping track of the payments but leave the United States subject to suit when the person who has authority to do -- Page 16 do these things goofs.  I mean, what -- what trouble has the United States saved itself?  It would still have to ride herd over -- over the person with -- with whom it's dealing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But the -- the Justice Department has no authority to -- to consent to suit which -- which Congress has not consented to. I don't see how this strengthens your case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And this alone wouldn't -- wouldn't remedy the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- the absence --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You may, indeed, Mr. Smiland. Mr. Minear, I think you're up next.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Minear, do you think it does waive sovereign immunity for suits brought by the district?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Did this suit begin as a suit by a water user against the district and then you were joined later?  Is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, in this suit, did not the district bring it against the United States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And was that a -- was that Page 19 jurisdiction proper at that time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But was it properly brought is what I'm asking you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And no money damages.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So that -- so your view -- I mean, what -- what makes sense to me is that the section means what it says, that consent is given to join the United States.  That means join them in an ongoing suit. And it makes sense because what the United States wants is anyone who sues them for money damages goes to the Court of Claims.  But of course, where you have an ongoing suit between two other people, we'll make an exception because there it's already in another district and we'll let you bring the United States in as a necessary party.  The other exception is when you don't sue for money damages. Page 20 That's in section 702 of the APA. Now, that to me makes a lot of sense and it's consistent with the language.  Is that your view or do you have a different view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: May I -- may I -- has that always been your view throughout? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But throughout the litigation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There has to be an ongoing suit.  You think this section does -- does not permit somebody to initiate suit against one party and at the same time against the United States as a necessary party.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why what is the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- that is to say, there's a suit between only two individuals and then the United States is brought in.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I understand that.  That's one situation that this provision could cover, but there are other situations that this provision could -- could cover. Let's say a farmer wants to bring suit against the district, but it doesn't really know whether the fault is with the district or whether the district was -- was compelled to do what it did by the United States.  So it sues the district and just in case the United States was -- was responsible, it joins the United States.  Why doesn't the language entirely permit that kind of a suit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Then -- then how do you explain the last -- the last sentence of that provision, which is any suit pursuant to this section?  The only suit that the section refers to is a suit in which the United States is joined as a necessary party defendant.  That's the subject of the section.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and the last sentence says, any suit pursuant to this section may be brought in any United States district court.  And I read that to mean if you want to sue the United States as a necessary party initiating a suit, you can bring it in -- in any district court in which the land involved is. Page 23

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Minear, when you say -- when you say not money damages, do you read the words that I read to Mr. Smiland restrictively or do you think they accommodate money damages, that is, suit to adjudicate, confirm, validate, or decree the contractual rights of a contracting entity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So money damages -- waiver always used the word money damages.  When it says adjudicate the rights under the contract, that doesn't include money damages?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What about the second sentence? The United States, when a party, shall be deemed to have waived any right to plead that it is not amenable thereto by reason of its sovereignty and shall be subject to judgments, orders, and decrees of the court having jurisdiction and may obtain review thereof in the same manner and to the same extent?  It's subject to the judgments, orders, and decrees of the court to the same extent as a private individual under like circumstances. Page 25 Why isn't that enough to -- to say that the court can -- can award damages?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but if contractual rights include a right to be paid for something, why wouldn't you get a money judgment in a case like that?  That first sentence certainly covers the possibility of a contractual right to be paid something.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: That's pretty clear language.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Certainly if it were not a -- a United States and were a private individual, it would Page 26 include money damages.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And -- and the next sentence, as Justice Scalia points out, says the United States shall be treated just like a private party.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, I think you've got a very strong argument when you talk about an incidental third party beneficiary not being a contracting party, but now you're asking for a much broader holding than really necessary to dispose of this case, it seems to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Separate from -- where does that -- that obligation come from?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's a State -- a State- created obligation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, you don't take the position, do you, that Westlands could have agreed with the United States that it wouldn't enforce its new laws that deprived the farmers of water?  You don't take that position.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes, but you can't -- the -- presumably the Federal Government can't negotiate away the Endangered Species Act or something.  The fact is that new laws were passed after these contracts were entered into with Westlands.  Isn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can the district get damages from the Government?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Minear. Mr. Somach, will you tell us what the district's views on this whole matter are?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me.  Could you expand on the first point a little bit?  I mean, you say you don't want to be bothered with lawsuits.  Is -- is that -- is that all that it amounts to?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can't -- can't such a suit be brought in State court?  I can't believe that this district can do whatever it wants with the water.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Really?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I don't really understand why that's any greater burden than the fact they can sue you in State court anyway.  They -- they can always bring litigation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, the suit in State court, I assume, would -- would only be -- the claim would be that you were acting arbitrarily, and so long as your interpretation of the contract was a reasonable one, the suit would fail.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Whereas, this suit here -- it doesn't matter how reasonable it is.  If it's wrong, it's wrong.  I mean, it's quite a different --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What about the provision in the judgment at page 110 that was -- that was cited to us, that -- that the parties may obtain other appropriate relief by the filing of a new action?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Somach. Mr. Smiland, you have 9 minutes remaining, but Page 40 you do not have to use it all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, you say under the contract.  I thought there was a provision in the contract that said that the United States will not be responsible for under-deliveries, and I think it listed the drought and the last thing was any other cause.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you were saying there's -- there's a right under this contract to recover from the United States for an under-delivery.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, please.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No.  I've asked a lot of questions.  Go on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What do you make -- excuse me. What do you make of the argument for reasonable construction of the contract that in fact you just simply cannot have a system that would promise the chaos that -- that you are promising?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is -- is it correct, as Justice Scalia suggested earlier, that so far as State litigation is concerned, it would be limited simply to arbitrary, unreasonable behavior?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I think it's arbitrary not to -- not to -- for an agency, of which you're -- you're in some sense at least the beneficiary, not to insist upon its contract rights, just as a shareholder can insist that the -- that a corporation enforce its contracts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, he was wrong.  That was -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I guess the reason that you would sue the district would be if you didn't have any enforceable promise from the United States that they didn't -- wouldn't do it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, you think you do.  That's the issue in the case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And so therefore -- therefore, I'm looking for where that promise is.  And you started out by citing a page, which wasn't a page of the contract. Page 43 It was a page of some kind of settlement, and that page said that the district agrees that they entered into the contract with helping the farmers in mind. I'm sure they did. So what. I mean, I might buy a house with the idea of helping of my child. I'm going to give it to him. That doesn't mean he can enforce the contract.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You mean my child can enforce a contract I enter into with another -- I buy a house and I say I intend to give it to my daughter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And then she can enforce the contract?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes. If the contract says. Now, that's why I was interested that you didn't cite language in the contract.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You -- well, I mean, you started out by referring me to page 110 or 111 --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- which doesn't. Now, what is the language in the contract --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- that helps you the most? Page 44

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Smiland. The case is taken under advisement.
